Award.AwardTitle: Development of a H in Feldspar Magmatic Hygrometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
Water exerts a strong influence on the physical and chemical properties of magmas. In order to understand dynamic processes associated with magma chambers and volcanic eruptions, it is therefore crucial to document variations and evolution of magmatic H2O contents through the stages of crystallization, differentiation, degassing, and eruption. This project has as a central goal to develop a new method for estimating magmatic H2O by determining experimentally how the element hydrogen (H) is partitioned between the ubiquitous feldspar minerals and silicate liquids, or magmas.

The new technique to be developed in this study will complement existing methods such as melt inclusion studies, constraints from phase equilibria, and albite-anorthite (Ab-An) hygrometry. The team will conduct experiments over a range of temperatures, bulk H2O contents, and oxygen fugacities. The experiments will focus on plagioclase (An25-An90) and coexisting basaltic-rhyolitic melt compositions. The experiments will be supplemented by analyses of natural plagioclase/melt inclusion pairs from Mt. Hood and Mt. Mazama, Oregon. These samples provide a test case for this method because they have already been studied using melt inclusion and Ab-An hygrometry. They will analyze hydrogen in both experimental and natural samples by SIMS, using a newly developed calibration for feldspars. At the same time, they plan to use new electron microprobe (EPMA) analyses to provide new constraints on thermodynamic models of Ab-An hygrometry. Broader impacts of the study include providing opportunities for direct participation by undergraduates in the research process, collaboration with Phil Ihinger at UW Eau Claire (a principally undergraduate research institution), and development of feldspar standards as part of this project that will be disseminated to SIMS laboratories in the Earth Science community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transfer, storage, and release of magmatic water and other volatiles through, within, and from the crust is important to global chemical cycling, crustal differentiation, and the dynamics of volcanic eruptions. Volatiles fundamentally influence the chemical and physical properties of liquids. Furthermore, bubble formation resulting from degassing upon supersaturation is a major driver of eruptions. Therefore, an important task of igneous petrology entails documenting variations in magmatic volatile contents through the various stages of crystallization, differentiation, degassing, and eruption. The major goal of the project was to develop a new hygrometer for igneous rocks based on the partitioning of hydrogen between feldspars and melts, both through experimental determinations and study of natural volcanic systems. 

We made progress in our goals by acquiring new experimental data on the incorporation of hydrogen in plagioclase and by studying H and F concentrations in arc volcanic rocks from Crater Lake and Mount Hood in the Cascadian volcanic arc. Our new experimental data demonstrate an important effect of oxygen fugacity on hydrogen solubility (H solubility goes up by a factor of 2-3 at low oxygen fugacity fixed by the iron-wustite buffer, compared to higher oxygen fugacities more relevant to modern-day arc volcanic settings). Preliminary partitioning experiments suggest that this effect is also relevant at higher temperatures in the presence of a melt. We have developed a crystallographic model to explain our observations. In addition to providing fundamental information on the mechanisms for storing hydrogen in the most common mineral in the Earth's crust (and in the Moon), this result has potentially important implications for processes in the formation of the early Earth and the Moon that are affected by trace amounts of volatiles.

Our studies use a recently developed and refined microanalytical technique (SIMS) that permits greater spatial resolution than FTIR, the technique used in previous studies. This has enabled us to document concentration profiles in the natural samples (owing to diffusional loss during eruption and emplacement) and determine the maximum H and F concentrations for each phenocryst, which is important for estimating the partition coefficients for these elements. In total we collected over 800 analyses on phenocrysts from three eruptions of Mount Hood and eight eruptions of Crater Lake. Our data, in combination with new and previously published data on H2O and F in melt inclusions, has enabled us to place new constraints on partitioning that will be useful to other researchers seeking to use this technique as a hygrometer. 

This study provided educational opportunities for one M.S. graduate student who hopes to use her experience and skills in science education, and one undergraduate student who has gone on to pursue a Ph.D. in experimental petrology and volcanology at the University of Rhode Island. We anticipate that our results, when published, will be useful for other researchers seeking to use this technique to place constraints on magmatic volatile evolution in other settings.
